PostValue.explanation: This is a localized, practical request about funding and structuring a research project to influence Tasmanian policy. It is not advancing a foundational claim for EA priorities (e.g., AI safety or global health), so it is only modestly relevant to EAers interested in policy, advocacy, or funding mechanisms. If successful it could matter for Tasmania’s governance, but it has very limited global scale or theoretical importance, so it is low-impact for humanity overall.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Missing research framing and feasibility — The post is too vague to turn into a PhD/postdoc proposal. Actionable fixes: (a) state a clear research question (e.g. “What institutional reforms enabled rapid economic modernization in Norway and Singapore, and which of these are transferable to Tasmania?”), (b) pick 1–2 methods (comparative case study + process tracing, archival research, elite interviews, or policy experiments) and describe the data you can access, (c) add realistic scope and timeline (PhD = 3–4 years, what a pilot year would show). This will make it credible to supervisors and funders.  

2) Dangerous/unclear assumption of transferability — Treating Norway and Singapore as blueprints for Tasmania ignores huge contextual differences (scale, resource basis, political culture, legal constraints, international position) and problematic political trade-offs (e.g. Singapore’s authoritarian elements). Actionable fixes: explicitly acknowledge these differences, add a paragraph on “what transferability means” (policy transfer vs. imitation vs. learning), and include criteria for evaluating suitability (political feasibility, legal compatibility, public acceptability). Consider comparing many small, democratic cases rather than focusing only on Norway/Singapore.  

3) No plan for academic pathway or stakeholder strategy — The question about turning this into a PhD/postdoc needs concrete next steps. Actionable fixes: list potential host disciplines (comparative politics, public policy, development studies, political economy), suggest target universities and supervisors with relevant work (names if you can), describe what funders will expect (proposal, ethics approval, CV, prior research or pilot), and outline stakeholder engagement (Tasmanian government contacts, local universities, civil society) and risk management (political sensitivities, ethics, reputational risks). If you want help, share whether you want an academic route or a policy/consultancy route so advice can be tailored.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets the key flaws: extreme vagueness, a naive assumption of direct transferability from Norway/Singapore to Tasmania, and lack of an academic or stakeholder pathway. These are major issues the author would likely be embarrassed about if unchallenged, and the suggested fixes are concrete and actionable (research question, methods, scope, disciplines, engagement). It could be improved by briefly advising to soften the rhetorical framing (e.g. avoid ‘make Tasmania the Norway down-under’) and by pointing to the policy-transfer literature as a starting point, but overall the feedback is highly useful.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No identifiable presence of an author named 'Franklin Jack' in EA/rationalist publications, forums (LessWrong, EA Forum), or major academic/press sources up to my knowledge cutoff. Likely a pseudonym or very minor/obscure author; not known within EA circles and no detectable global profile. If you can provide links or context (works, handles), I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is short, readable and communicates a clear, simple request (how to turn a funded project about political transformations into a PhD/postdoc). However it lacks key details that would make the ask actionable: it doesn't define terms (what counts as a 'revolution' or 'Norway down-under'), justify choice of case studies (Norway, Singapore), specify research questions, methods, disciplinary fit, or intended outcomes/stakeholders. Concise but missing necessary specificity.

PostNovelty.explanation: This proposal is largely a straightforward, common idea: commissioning comparative research on successful state-building/policy transfers and turning it into academic work is well-trodden (development studies, comparative politics, policy transfer literature). The only mildly specific aspect is applying Norway/Singapore-style lessons to Tasmania, but that is a narrow, incremental twist rather than a fundamentally new concept. Asking how to convert such work into a PhD/Postdoc is routine academic/practical planning rather than an original intellectual claim.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This post is essentially a high-level proposal/question rather than an argued thesis. Strengths: a clear goal (wanting to learn from other countries to improve Tasmania) and initiative on fundraising. Weaknesses: almost no reasoning about why Norway or Singapore are the right comparisons, no articulation of causal mechanisms, no discussion of feasibility or political constraints, no operationalization of outcomes, and no methodological plan. There is no empirical evidence or citation of relevant literature; key issues like differences in scale, history, institutions, and international context are not addressed. To be persuasive it would need comparative-case reasoning, identification of mechanisms, metrics for success, acknowledgment of counterfactuals and constraints, and a concrete research design (process tracing, mixed methods, etc.).

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Mixed / uncertain. The post’s implicit empirical claims break into two parts: (1) Norway and Singapore are plausible examples of highly “successful” political/economic transformations — this is well supported by historical and economic data (high GDP per capita, well‑documented development strategies, Norway’s sovereign wealth fund). (2) The unstated claim that those models can be straightforwardly implemented to make Tasmania “the Norway down‑under” is much weaker: Tasmania is a subnational Australian jurisdiction with limited taxation/fiscal autonomy, very different resource endowments (no equivalent to Norway’s petroleum revenues) and different institutional constraints; policy‑transfer literature warns that lessons do not transfer automatically and context matters. In short: the choice of Norway and Singapore as successful cases is supported, but the feasibility claim (replicating them in Tasmania) is uncertain and not empirically validated without detailed comparative research.
sources: Norges Bank Investment Management — Government Pension Fund Global, Annual report 2024 (GPFG value and description)
World Bank / World Development Indicators — GDP per capita (current US$) (data underlying Norway and Singapore per‑capita comparisons)
MacroTrends — Singapore GDP per capita (1960–2023) (World Bank data mirror)
MacroTrends — Norway GDP per capita (1960–2023) (World Bank data mirror)
Encyclopaedia Britannica — History and development of Singapore (Lee Kuan Yew, 1959–1990) and Singapore economy overview
Encyclopaedia Britannica / other reliable histories — Norway history and post‑WWII welfare/oil era overview
Australian Bureau of Statistics — National, state and territory population (Sep 2024) (Tasmania population data)
Australian Bureau of Statistics / State Accounts (GSP per capita, 2023–24) (Tasmania GSP per capita and economic scale)

Australian Government Treasury / Parliamentary Education Office — history of Australia’s uniform income tax (1942) and federal‑state fiscal relations (shows states’ limited income tax powers and reliance on Commonwealth grants)
Dolowitz, D. & Marsh, D. (2000) 'Learning from Abroad: the Role of Policy Transfer in Contemporary Policy‑Making', Governance (framework and caveats on policy transfer)
James, O. & Lodge, M. (2003) 'The Limitations of Policy Transfer and Lesson Drawing' (critique on transferability/context dependence)
